posts.name: Gage Caswell
posts.cooked: Our team has recently updated our libraries from 2024 and migrated to PhoenixV6. After the migration, one of our modules on our swerve drive isn’t working as intended, specifically the angle motor ( CAN ID 1) of module 1. So far, we have replaced the SparkMAX motor controller and the NEO motor, neither of which have remedied the issue. The SparkMAX status light shows solid cyan when the robot should be driving, which I believe is the brushless brake mode status light. All CANcoders seem to functioning as intended, and that modules angle motor is the only one with an issue. We have sort of hit a wall on where to progress from here, so if anyone has any ideas on what the issue may be, that would be much appreciated!

You can try to trace the wires and ensure the connections are all good, if they are then you probably have a bad sparkmax and/or bad motor.

Check for this failure if you can

NEO Overheat The Serial Killer Motor

posts.name: Gage Caswell
posts.cooked:
We just ran through the test. While the encoder connector was unplugged from the SparkMAX itself, we received no resistance value. When we did plug it in to the SparkMAX and measure from there, we did receive a resistance value. In the slideshow, it showed it with the encoder disconnected, so I don’t believe that would be issue.

Also, the motors and SparkMAX’s have been replaced, and we are able to turn the motor through the REV client.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: I doubt this would work, but try a CAN ID other than 1?
You would be surprised! One of my teams had a SparkMAX CAN ID that was the same as the PDH CAN ID and when they changed the ID of the SparkMAX it worked!

posts.name: Gage Caswell
posts.cooked: I just swapped the CAN ID of that motor, and the issue persisted.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: Yes… We have had that issue but I could not remember which were the default ids for roborio and PDP

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: So do you believe this is a software issue? Also, is your software able to read values from the motor?

posts.name: Gage Caswell
posts.cooked: We are able to read values from the CANcoder, I am not sure how we would read the values from the absolute encoder.

posts.name: Gage Caswell
posts.cooked: Every other motor seems to be reading values successfully, however.

posts.name: Gage Caswell
posts.cooked: Update: Just for the sake of testing, we swapped the drive/angle motor CAN ID’s within the code, and both motors started turning (obviously not correctly). It seems that it is an issue with the absolute encoder, I will post any updates if I figure it out.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: Hmm… Interesting… Could you maybe run the code and then with rev hardware client check that the CAN IDs are the same as before? Not sure if thats even a reasonable test but worth a shot.

posts.name: Gage Caswell
posts.cooked:
It’s been a few days and the issue has not been resolved, so here is a bit of an update.

Could you maybe run the code and then with rev hardware client check that the CAN IDs are the same as before?

We ran this tests and the CAN IDs remained within the REV hardware client. We also changed the CAN IDs within the code and client, but the issue persisted.

image 865×436 9.67 KB

image 865×436 9.67 KB

image 865×436 9.67 KB

These are some of the values we receive while the robot is being fed inputs from the controller. Note the modules are not aligned currently aligned correctly, as it would be unnecessary to set offsets while we still have a non-functional module.

I am going to try and see if the motor controller is receiving the correct values from the code, any suggestions help!
